title: Can we learn lessons from loneliness? - Quora

response.answer_text: I learned a valuable lesson dealing with loneliness. Fighting through depression and anxiety, I discovered something about myself that had been holding me back for more than two decades. I used to hate being alone. If I was left alone at home, at work, or even when friends separated during an outing, I was weighed down my loneliness. The weight brought on questions like, “am I even worth it? Do I matter? Why me?” These are questions I asked, among others, for a long time. It wasn’t until I started asking “why” and looking through my past for answers. Why did I feel lonely? Why did I hate being alone? Why did I get depressed or anxious when alone? I found answers to all of these questions in a consistent disciplinary routine my parents enacted when I disobeyed as a child. As a child, if I disobeyed, they would send me to my room and make me wait for an undefined period of time, alone. At the end of this waiting, I would either get a spanking or be talked to sternly about what I did wrong, why it was wrong, and why it’s important to obey. The general sadness of disappointing my parents on top of the anxiety of not knowing when I was going to encounter a negative experience turned into depression and anxiety as an adult. I learned two things from loneliness: Ask what is causing the loneliness (search your entire life for examples of the same feeling in different moments).Ask why you still hold onto these feelings, even though that moment has passed.These two steps changed my life. I write for a living. I spend a lot of time “alone,” but I no longer see being alone as a punishment or potential negative situation full of depression or anxiety. I see my alone time as an opportunity to better myself, my craft, or the world around me. When I asked what and why of my loneliness, it eventually gave me a reason why it still haunted me. And as most people know, once you point a flashlight at the monster under the bed, we realize it’s an old jacket, not a creature wanting to eat us. Shine a light on your loneliness. Figure out what’s causing it and why it’s causing it. Then, evolve.

I think what we can learn from loneliness varies individually. To me, it could be any or all of the following: It can teach us to empathize. Everyone experiences loneliness. It is ”commonplace.” We all know how it is to feel lonely. This socially shared cognition makes us capable of feeling for others. It can teach us to be attuned to ourselves. It can be a time for us to understand our emotions, triggers, aspirations, or frustrations, with more depth. If you wanna know what makes you lonely you have to let yourself dig deeper. It validates the idea that happiness requires conscious effort. Life is a constant decision-making process - from the smallest to the major things in life. And when you’re lonely, you know you have difficult and pressing decisions to make if you want to move forward. And you have to employ your resolve because indecision will not bring you any further. It can help us rekindle our values. Loneliness can remind us of the things that really matter to us and give us a new or renewed appreciation of them and a fresh motivation to change the way we tackle challenges in life. It can bring out your fortitude when you finally decide to revamp your life. It also teaches us to be comfortable with being vulnerable. Loneliness does not happen to weak people. It happens to people. When we’re lonely we recognize our need for support from our friends and family, or our need for divine help. It naturally propels us to stay connected. Some people turn to isolation but that’s a different story.

The other answers here are all correct, in that being alone can teach you how to be with yourself, how to be in your own thoughts, and other important lessons. BUT… I would add that true loneliness, as I've experienced it, is a feeling of disconnection from everyone and everything around you. It can be incredibly frightening and feeds on itself, as the more you feel it, the more you isolate. I'd say the most important lesson I've learned from loneliness is how much alone time I can have before 'loneliness' sets in. My limit is 2 days. Then I need to be with people, or I start feeling that disconnection. Everything difficult we experience in this life has lessons for us. But I would say the best thing you can learn from loneliness (as opposed to just being alone), is how to ensure you feel connected to the people and world around you.

Absolutely. Loneliness is a gift, my dear, don’t squander it. It is a harsh teacher, but an effective one. It will teach you empathy for others, give you a quiet place for introspection and eventually the drive to go out there one more time and try out these humans again. Once you are out of it, you’ll appreciate those in your life so much more. You’ll help others out of it and back into the group.

Yes. We can learn from everything. But the question is, will we — and do we really want to? Loneliness is a mindset in my opinion. It’s also a test. There is tremendous inner strength gained from building the ability to be alone, and having contentment with and finding joy when in solitude. That is the same environment where loneliness occurs. The only difference — and it is an BIG difference — is how one internalizes and chooses to think or feel about the situation and oneself at such times. The above is my own personal lesson from loneliness; not something I have read or heard said by others. But my own firsthand experience at x time, feeling alone and lonely. I changed how I interpreted it; how I thought about it; and the feeling held for it. In essence, I changed and all loneliness ended. What took its place was an ability to be, and passion for spending time, alone. So, yes lessons are there for the learning. It’s not a matter of “can we” but do we want to, and are we willing to put in the effort?
